title.ph: Developing Content in the Oxygen XML Authoring Tool

conbody.p: The Darwin Information Typing Architecture (DITA) specification defines a set of document types for authoring and organizing topic-oriented information. It is an open standard. that is defined and maintained by the OASIS DITA Technical Committee.
The name derives from the following components:

ul.li: Darwin: because it uses the principles of specialization and inheritance, which is analogous to Charles Darwin's concept of evolutionary adaptation.
Information Typing: which means each topic has a defined primary objective and structure.
Architecture: DITA is an extensible set of structures.

section.title: What are Topics?
section.p: A topic is a unit of information with a title and content, short enough to be specific to a single subject or answer a single question, but long enough to make sense on its own and be authored as a unit. Topics are the basis for high-quality information.

Information typing is the practice of identifying types of topics that contain distinct kinds information, such as concepts, tasks, and reference information. Topics that answer different kinds of questions can be categorized under different information types. The base topic types provided by DITA (a generic topic, plus concept, task, and reference ) provide a starter set that can be adopted for immediate authoring.

section.title: What are the DITA Topic Types?
section.p: DITA includes three main topic types: Task, Concept, and Reference.

ul.li: Tasks are used to describe how to perform a procedure, for example, to install a product.
Concepts present descriptive information to understand the background or context of a product.
Reference topics provide detailed facts such as product specifications, often in a table.

section.title: What is the structure of a topic?
section.p: The DITA standard defines how each topic type is structured. All topics have the same basic structure, regardless of the topic type.
Every topic contains some common elements, like Title, Prolog (for metadata like audience, category, keywords), Short Description, as well as some that are unique.

task.shortdesc: Create a concept topic using Oxygen XML Author.

context.p: A concept topic provides background that helps readers understand essential information about a product, a task, a process, or any other conceptual or descriptive information. Use this procedure to create a concept topic using Oxygen XML Author.

step.cmd: Open an instance of Oxygen XML Author.
Frm the top left hand corner, click FileNew
step.stepresult: The Choose a file template dialog box displays.

step.cmd: Create a concept topic as follows:

substep.cmd: In the field provided, type concept.
Choose Concept [DITA / Topics]
In the Title field, enter a name for your concept topic.
Observe the path on your computer where the file is being created. Ensure that the path is correct.
Click Create.

task.shortdesc: Create a task topic using Oxygen XML Author.

context.p: A task topic contains a single procedure, which is made up of a series of steps. Each step describes a single action or command for the user to take. A step can also describe the step results. One or more task topics typically follow each concept topic. Use this procedure to create a task topic using Oxygen XML Author.

step.cmd: Open an instance of Oxygen XML Author.
Frm the top left hand corner, click FileNew
step.stepresult: The Choose a file template dialog box displays.

step.cmd: Create a task topic as follows:

substep.cmd: In the field provided, type task.
Choose Task [DITA / Topics]
In the Title field, enter a name for your task topic.
Observe the path on your computer where the file is being created. Ensure that the path is correct.
Click Create.

task.shortdesc: Create a reference topic using Oxygen XML Author.

context.p: Reference topics provide quick access to fact-based information. In technical information, reference topics are used to list product specifications and parameters, provide essential data, and provide detailed information on subjects such as the commands in a programming language. Use this procedure to create a task topic using Oxygen XML Author.

step.cmd: Open an instance of Oxygen XML Author.
Frm the top left hand corner, click FileNew
step.stepresult: The Choose a file template dialog box displays.

step.cmd: Create a task topic as follows:

substep.cmd: In the field provided, type task.
Choose Reference
In the Title field, enter a name for your reference topic.
Observe the path on your computer where the file is being created. Ensure that the path is correct.
Click Create.

concept.shortdesc: Explains DITA maps at a high level.

conbody.p: DITA maps are XML documents that organize topics and other resources into structured collections of information. DITA maps specify hierarchy and the relationships among the topics. DITA maps typically have . ditamap file extensions.

DITA maps are key components for authoring DITA content. Managing these files and their referenced topics is an important feature of a DITA editor. The DITA Maps Manager in Oxygen enables you to view and edit DITA map files.

task.shortdesc: Create a ditamap using Oxygen XML Author.

context.p: DITA maps are documents that organize topics and other resources into structured collections of information. DITA maps specify hierarchy and the relationships among the topics; they also provide the context in which keys are defined and resolved. DITA maps should have . ditamap file extensions. Use this procedure to create a ditamap using Oxygen XML Author.

step.cmd: Open an instance of Oxygen XML Author.
Frm the top left hand corner, click FileNew
step.stepresult: The Choose a file template dialog box displays.

step.cmd: Create a map as follows:

substep.cmd: In the field provided, type map.
Choose Map [DITA / Topics]
In the Title field, enter a name for your map.
Observe the path on your computer where the file is being created. Ensure that the path is correct.
Click Create.

title.ph: Publishing DITA XML outputs in Oxygen
Publishing outputs from DITA XML using Oxygen

context.p: Use this procedure to publish outputs using the built-in default XSL transforms available with the Oxygen XML authoring tool.

note.p: XSL Transforms (XSLT) process XML documents to convert them to HTML format. XSLT is a language originally designed for transforming XML documents into formats such as HTML for web pages, plain text etc., which may subsequently be further converted to other formats such as PDF.

step.cmd: Invoke an instance of the Oxygen XML editor on your computer.
Click FileOpen to navigate to the location of the main ditamap (that contains other maps and topics) on your system.
Click DITA Maps Manager.
Click Configure Transformation Scenario(s).
step.info: The Configure Transformation Scenario(s) dialog box displays.

step.cmd: Select one or all the following transforms:

ul.li: DITA Map WebHelp Responsive to publish a web help output.
DITA Map PDF - based on HTML5 & CSS to publish a PDF
DITA Map HTML5 to publish a HTML5 output.

step.cmd: Click Apply associated.
step.stepresult:
The transformation begins. You can view the progress in the progress bar at the bottom of the editor.
Once published, your system automatically displays the published outputs - namely PDF, HTML and Web help.

taskbody.prereq: Before you begin, ensure that you create a public GitHub repository to upload the DITA XML source files.

context.p: You must upload DITA XML source files from the locally stored folder on your computer to the GitHub repository, so that the files and the published outputs can be viewed publicly.

step.cmd: Go to .
Click the link to your public repository (for example, DITA-XML sample) under Top repositories on the left hand side of the web page.
step.stepresult: The repository opens up in the web page as follows:

step.cmd: Click uploading an existing file.
Drag and drop the entire folder from your local folder to the repository, in the space provided.

info.note: Ensure that you upload the entire folder with all the supporting files like images etc., to the repository.

step.cmd: Click Commit Changes.
step.stepresult: All your source files are committed to GitHub.

title.ph: Sharing outputs using the public GitHub Repository

task.shortdesc: Share your published documentation with your audience.

taskbody.prereq:
Ensure that you have uploaded the entire folder containing the XML source files from your computer to the GitHub public repository. When you upload the folders from your computer to the GitHub repository, ensure that you preserve the same folder structure. You will typically notice the following sub folders within the out folder containing the outputs you want to share with your audience.
html5 - containing the files required for the HTML5 output.
pdf-css-html5 - containing the files required for the PDF output.
webhelp-responsive - containing the files required for the web help output.

context.p: The GitHub repository enables you to access the source code for your content, but not the content itself. Use this procedure to enable your audience to access your published outputs (HTML, PDF or WebHelp) using the public GitHub repository.

step.cmd: On an instance of web brower, type , and sign in.
From the top left hand side corner, navigate to your pubic repository on GitHub.
Double-click the out folder to view its contents.
Do the following to share the HTML5 output from GitHub.

substep.cmd: Double-click the html5 folder on GitHub.
Click the index.html file.
substep.info: The file opens in the browser, and the URL will be something like this: https://github.com/MickeyMouse123/SampleFolder/blob/main/out/html5/index.html

substep.cmd: To enable your audience to view the content on GitHub:
substep.info: Prefix the above URL with:https://htmlpreview.github.io/?so that the URL finally becomes:https://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/MickeyMouse123/SampleFolder/blob/main/out/html5/index.html

substep.cmd: Share this URL with your audience.
